message: found this on reddit http://science.io/
@Vasil  thank you for that!
I wish it were more useful. It's a great idea, but there is no incentive for academics to improve the content.

If you think the content of some papers are too weak, you can always to your own research and write an own paper, that deals with these shortcomings ;) I also read many articles/papers where I think the findings were quite obvious anyway. But why should I blame "academics" for that?
For instance there are a total of 15 papers added to Astronomy. That's less than the average added to astro-ph (the arxiv's astronomy section) every single day.
The papers on science.io are fine. That's not the issue.
The problem is that not enough people in the field use it for the curations and favs to be useful/accurate.
And there are 0 comments...
Many people have tried the rate/review/comment on this journal article format site, but none of them have ever gotten scientists involved because there is no reason for them to do so. Sad really.

Yes, but that's the problem for every new platform, isn't it? It's the same here as well ... it could take quite a while, until a critical mass uses something. It may also never happen ... the question is: how could that be changed? In my opinion basically just by contributing. By building content, rating, writing comments, until there is enough interesting content, that attracts more people. It's time-consuming and sort of risky, but I have no other idea than this. People don't come, when there's nothing to see ...
One possibility to populate it would be to make it compulsory somehow. Maybe necessary to get into a conference?
@justinlilly That is kind of brilliant. Most active users get picked for some sciencey vip stuff.

@goetz right but the people in this case are academics. It has proven incredibly difficult to get them to use any platform beyond journals. I think Mendeley (http://mendeley.com) is doing the best job so far.
@caseywstark Thank you! I just signed up there to take a look at that site ...

academics are people too. You have to provide them with something they want. One sure-fire way to get academics to use your platform is to offer them grants, or perhaps make it VERY easy for other people to give them grants. etc.
thing I read recently says that 40% of an academic's time is seeking funding.
"academics are people too" -- this is a nefaruius lie!  they are not people, and I won't believe it unless I see a peer reviewed paper confirming it
@justinlilly It depends on what you consider seeking funding, but that seems super high.
Some people have suggested that scientists should involve the public more in funding, a la kickstarter, but there are very large barriers to both scientists and the public to make that happen.
The easy grant thing would definitely help, but only works for small projects. You still need the giant agencies for the big goal science.
